terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and see who made specific modifications.
A feature that monitors and records all modifications made to a document, showing what was changed, when, and by whom.
The structured process and sequence of steps involved in creating, reviewing, editing, and publishing documentation within an organization.
A software development methodology that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, and iterative improvement through short development cycles.
A chronological record of all changes, edits, and versions of a document, allowing users to see the evolution of content over time.
Situations that occur when multiple users make conflicting changes to the same document or code, requiring manual resolution to combine the changes.
Software platforms and applications designed to help teams work together on projects, share information, and communicate effectively.
The accuracy, consistency, and reliability of data throughout its lifecycle, ensuring information remains unchanged and trustworthy.
Security measures that determine who can view, edit, or manage specific documents or systems within an organization.
Documentation that can be integrated or inserted into other websites, applications, or platforms while maintaining its original formatting and functionality.
Artificial Intelligence-powered technology that automatically converts text from one language to another, often used for content localization.
The process of adapting content to meet the language, cultural, and regional preferences of specific target audiences or markets.
Established guidelines and standards for creating, maintaining, and organizing documentation to ensure quality, consistency, and usability.
Internet-based computing services that provide storage, processing power, and applications accessible from anywhere with an internet connection.
The process of verifying a user's identity before granting access to systems, documents, or applications, typically through passwords or other credentials.
